title: Angiopoietin-like proteins stimulate HSPC development through interaction with notch receptor signaling
abstract: Angiopoietin-like proteins <italic>(angptls)</italic> are capable of ex vivo expansion of mouse and human hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells (HSPCs). Despite this intriguing ability, their mechanism is unknown. In this study, we show that <italic>angptl2</italic> overexpression is sufficient to expand definitive HSPCs in zebrafish embryos. <italic>Angptl1/2</italic> are required for definitive hematopoiesis and vascular specification of the hemogenic endothelium. The loss-of-function phenotype is reminiscent of the <italic>notch</italic> mutant <italic>mindbomb (mib)</italic>, and a strong genetic interaction occurs between <italic>angptls</italic> and <italic>notch</italic>. Overexpressing <italic>angptl2</italic> rescues <italic>mib</italic> while overexpressing <italic>notch</italic> rescues <italic>angptl1/2</italic> morphants. Gene expression studies in ANGPTL2-stimulated CD34<sup>+</sup> cells showed a strong <italic>MYC</italic> activation signature and <italic>myc</italic> overexpression in <italic>angptl1/2</italic> morphants or <italic>mib</italic> restored HSPCs formation. ANGPTL2 can increase NOTCH activation in cultured cells and ANGPTL receptor interacted with NOTCH to regulate NOTCH cleavage. Together our data provide insight to the <italic>angptl</italic>-mediated <italic>notch</italic> activation through receptor interaction and subsequent activation of <italic>myc</italic> targets.
